elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

      

Highlights

   ⋅ A rare structural topology based on copper hydroxide layers is observed in [Cu3(OH)4(oba)] n  (1).   ⋅ Compound 1 exhibits excellent water oxidation catalysis activity in basic solution.   ⋅ Chronoamperometric studies show that 1 reaches a current density of 0.1mAcm-2 at η=576mV.   ⋅ Catalyst 1 showed a turnover frequency (TOF) of 2×10-3s-1 at 418mV.   ⋅ Compound 1 retains its structural integrity during catalytic reactions.

elements.clean_text:
A rare structural topology based on copper hydroxide layers is observed in [Cu3(OH)4(oba)] n  (1).

Compound 1 exhibits excellent water oxidation catalysis activity in basic solution.

Chronoamperometric studies show that 1 reaches a current density of 0.1mAcm-2 at η=576mV.

Catalyst 1 showed a turnover frequency (TOF) of 2×10-3s-1 at 418mV.

Compound 1 retains its structural integrity during catalytic reactions.

Abstract

An uncommon copper(II) hydroxide layer-based coordination polymer [Cu3(OH)4(oba)] n  (1) (oba=4,4'-oxybisbenzoate) has been synthesized and tested as electro-catalyst for water oxidation under basic conditions. In comparison to classical Cu(OH)2, 1 exhibits improved thermal stability of up to ca. 350°C. Chronoamperometry studies indicate that catalyst 1 reaches an anodic current density of 0.1mAcm-2 at η=576mV; a TOF of 2×10-3s-1 at 418mV overpotential value. The catalyst 1 shows Faradaic efficiency of 95%. Long-term catalytic studies for 10h at a constant potential of 1.2V indicate that compound 1 is robust and retains its chemical composition. Infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and cyclic voltammetry studies of the pristine and post-catalytic compound 1-coated FTO electrodes further confirm that 1 retains its structural integrity throughout the catalytic cycle. Our results represent a proof-of-concept for designing next-generation robust and improved OER electrocatalysts based on earth-abundant metals.

The OER is of great significance in the construction of rechargeable batteries, and is considered as one of the bottlenecks in the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> economy as water splitting entails the production of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> from H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. In this context, low over-potential, higher current densities and electro-catalyst durability are the parameters that are highly desirable for efficient electro-catalytic water splitting.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The increasing global energy requirement has added to the rising thrust in formulating renewable energy devices like solar cells and metal-air batteries . In both types of devices, the overall performance is mostly governed by the kinetics of the O2 evolution reaction (OER) and O2 reduction reaction (ORR). The OER is of great significance in the construction of rechargeable batteries, and is considered as one of the bottlenecks in the H2 economy as water splitting entails the production of H2 and O2 from H2O. In this context, low over-potential, higher current densities and electro-catalyst durability are the parameters that are highly desirable for efficient electro-catalytic water splitting.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The simultaneous proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) processes facilitate the climax of the redox equivalents crucial for multi-electron transformations that avoid high energy intermediates . Thus, PCET is a decisive step in many of the sustainable energy generation processes. A detailed mechanistic contemplation of the complicated water oxidation process has become possible because of PCET processes mediated by Ir and Ru based robust water oxidation catalysts . These studies indicated that: (i) the formation of a high-valent [M=O]<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n+</ce:sup>
</ce:italic> unit is mandatory and the accumulative charge of the catalyst is stabilized by the PCET process; and (ii) the crucial O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond-forming pace involves the nucleophilic attack of water molecule at the metal-oxo site (e.g. [Co<ce:sup loc="post">IV</ce:sup>=O]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
, [Ru<ce:sup loc="post">IV</ce:sup>=O]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, and [Ir<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup>=O]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The simultaneous proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) processes facilitate the climax of the redox equivalents crucial for multi-electron transformations that avoid high energy intermediates . Thus, PCET is a decisive step in many of the sustainable energy generation processes. A detailed mechanistic contemplation of the complicated water oxidation process has become possible because of PCET processes mediated by Ir and Ru based robust water oxidation catalysts . These studies indicated that: (i) the formation of a high-valent [M=O] n+  unit is mandatory and the accumulative charge of the catalyst is stabilized by the PCET process; and (ii) the crucial OO bond-forming pace involves the nucleophilic attack of water molecule at the metal-oxo site (e.g. [CoIV=O]2+ , [RuIV=O]2+, and [IrV=O]3+ .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The oxides of Ru  and Ir  are well known to offer high catalytic activities in OER. The cost and scarcity of such elements impede their wide-scale use. Hence, exploration of earth abundant metal, e.g. copper-based catalysts having adequate durability for electrochemical oxygen evolution at low over-potential is a central thrust . Electrocatalysts based on such comparably cheap metals, i.e. Fe , Co , Ni , and Cu, have been identified to be functional toward water oxidation reaction . Recent studies on copper oxide-based molecular moieties propose that copper(II) ions could initiate electrochemical water oxidation when residing in an environment of oxygen atoms , and the resulting activity is highly effected by the attached ligands . Mayer et al. reported the first copper-based water oxidation catalyst (WOC), i.e., [(Cu(bpy)(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, (bpy = 2,2′-bipyridyl)] in 2012 . Since then, many other copper-containing compounds, such as copper carbonate , copper peptides , or copper-dihydroxy-bpy system have been reported as WOCs . However, most of these electro-catalysts work at higher overpotentials and have not been investigated for their robustness during the catalytic activity over longer periods of time .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The oxides of Ru  and Ir  are well known to offer high catalytic activities in OER. The cost and scarcity of such elements impede their wide-scale use. Hence, exploration of earth abundant metal, e.g. copper-based catalysts having adequate durability for electrochemical oxygen evolution at low over-potential is a central thrust . Electrocatalysts based on such comparably cheap metals, i.e. Fe , Co , Ni , and Cu, have been identified to be functional toward water oxidation reaction . Recent studies on copper oxide-based molecular moieties propose that copper(II) ions could initiate electrochemical water oxidation when residing in an environment of oxygen atoms , and the resulting activity is highly effected by the attached ligands . Mayer et al. reported the first copper-based water oxidation catalyst (WOC), i.e., [(Cu(bpy)(OH)2, (bpy=2,2'-bipyridyl)] in 2012 . Since then, many other copper-containing compounds, such as copper carbonate , copper peptides , or copper-dihydroxy-bpy system have been reported as WOCs . However, most of these electro-catalysts work at higher overpotentials and have not been investigated for their robustness during the catalytic activity over longer periods of time .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Coordination polymers have captured great attention not only due to their structural fascination but potential applications in variety of fields i.e. heterogeneous catalysis , gas storage , magnetism  and luminescence  etc. Some CPs have also been proven to be good WOCs . Recently, Lin et al. have reported that a 4-(5-(pyridin-4-yl)-4H1,2,4-triazol-3-yl) benzoic acid-based Cu-MOF gives a current density of j = 0.48 mA cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> at + 1.4 V vs. SCE, an overpotential value of 780 mV and turnover number (TON) of 2.25 mol of O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> per mole of the catalyst. This catalyst also displayed 98% Faradaic efficiency . Ferdi et al. in 2016 have presented one-dimensional copper-based coordination polymer as a heterogeneous catalyst. This compound comprises Cu paddle-wheel units bridged via phosphine dioxide ligands. This catalyst offered a j value of 1 mA cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> at η = 563 mV . A Cu-based MOF with 6,6′-dihydroxy-2,2′-bipy ligands showed a j of 0.16 mA cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> at an η = 640 mV against NHE . In another study, the same Cu-polymer manifested an η = 520 mV for a j value of 0.80 mA cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> under different experimental conditions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers have captured great attention not only due to their structural fascination but potential applications in variety of fields i.e. heterogeneous catalysis , gas storage , magnetism  and luminescence  etc. Some CPs have also been proven to be good WOCs . Recently, Lin et al. have reported that a 4-(5-(pyridin-4-yl)-4H1,2,4-triazol-3-yl) benzoic acid-based Cu-MOF gives a current density of j=0.48mAcm-2 at+1.4V vs. SCE, an overpotential value of 780mV and turnover number (TON) of 2.25mol of O2 per mole of the catalyst. This catalyst also displayed 98% Faradaic efficiency . Ferdi et al. in 2016 have presented one-dimensional copper-based coordination polymer as a heterogeneous catalyst. This compound comprises Cu paddle-wheel units bridged via phosphine dioxide ligands. This catalyst offered a j value of 1mAcm-2 at η=563mV . A Cu-based MOF with 6,6'-dihydroxy-2,2'-bipy ligands showed a j of 0.16mAcm-2 at an η=640mV against NHE . In another study, the same Cu-polymer manifested an η=520mV for a j value of 0.80mAcm-2 under different experimental conditions .

<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Under facile solvothermal conditions, we have synthesized a coordination polymer, [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(oba)], where oba is 4,4′-oxybis(benzoate), <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> which possesses a rare topology. This newly synthesized compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains 2D cationic {[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> layers connected by the bent oba linkers to give an overall 3D network (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The copper(II) oxo skeleton in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is reminiscent of that in the metal-organic framework structure of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (where (C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)2) = 2,6-naphthalenedisulfonate (nds)), reported by Oliver and co-workers in 2010 and denoted as ARL-2 . Reactions of Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> cations with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oba are typically known to lead to the formation of metal organic frameworks based on copper(II) paddle-wheel structures . In order to synthesize <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the reaction was carried out in the presence of sodium molybdate. The presence of hydroxyl groups in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> inspired us to test this material as an electrocatalyst for water oxidation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Under facile solvothermal conditions, we have synthesized a coordination polymer, [Cu3(OH)4(oba)], where oba is 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate), (1) which possesses a rare topology. This newly synthesized compound 1 contains 2D cationic {[Cu3(OH)4]2+} n  layers connected by the bent oba linkers to give an overall 3D network (see  ). The copper(II) oxo skeleton in 1 is reminiscent of that in the metal-organic framework structure of [Cu3(OH)4[C10H6(SO3)2] (where (C10H6(SO3)2)=2,6-naphthalenedisulfonate (nds)), reported by Oliver and co-workers in 2010 and denoted as ARL-2 . Reactions of CuII cations with H2oba are typically known to lead to the formation of metal organic frameworks based on copper(II) paddle-wheel structures . In order to synthesize 1, the reaction was carried out in the presence of sodium molybdate. The presence of hydroxyl groups in 1 inspired us to test this material as an electrocatalyst for water oxidation.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Herein, we present the synthesis, characterization, crystal structure and electrochemical water oxidation of the novel and robust copper-based coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. To the best of our knowledge, it represents the first coordination polymer of its type, exclusively containing oxygen donor ligands, for water oxidation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Herein, we present the synthesis, characterization, crystal structure and electrochemical water oxidation of the novel and robust copper-based coordination polymer 1. To the best of our knowledge, it represents the first coordination polymer of its type, exclusively containing oxygen donor ligands, for water oxidation.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis of [Cu3(OH)4(oba)] n  (1) 

0.22g (1.0mmol) of Cu(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O and 0.12g (0.5mol) of Na2MoO4⋅2H2O were added to 2.5mL of distilled water and stirred. To this solution, 0.15g (0.5mmol) of 4,4'-oxybisbenzoic acid (H2oba) was added and the mixture was stirred again for 2-3min. The pH was adjusted and maintained at 5.29 by adding 0.5M HCl solution. The mixture (3mL) was poured into a glass vial and placed in an oven at 90°C for five days. Sky blue crystals of 1 were collected and washed with distilled water for several times. Yield: 51% based on Cu. Anal. calcd., Cu, 37.03; C, 32.66%; H, 2.35%;. Found: Cu, 36.85; C, 32.1%; H, 2.21%;. IR data (KBr pellet, ʋmax / cm-1): 3358m, 2965w, 1611s, 1397m, 1251s, 1164s, 993s, 777s, 671s, 627s. The IR data is shown in .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st040">Electrochemical studies</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The electrocatalytic and electrochemical measurements were carried out at room temperature using a Biologic-S300 potentiostat. For the electrochemical studies, a conventional three-electrode electrochemical cell containing an Ag/AgCl (3.5 M KCl) reference electrode, Pt wire auxiliary electrode, and fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) working electrode coated with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, respectively, was employed. FTO glass substrates were initially cleaned and compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-coated FTO working electrode was prepared as previously described<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>. All potentials described herein were measured in a phosphate buffer solution of pH = 10 (vs. Ag/AgCl). The cyclic voltammogram of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-coated FTO electrode was recorded between 0 and 1.6 V at a scan rate of 100 mV s<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The phosphate buffer solution will be abbreviated as KPi in this manuscript.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical studies

The electrocatalytic and electrochemical measurements were carried out at room temperature using a Biologic-S300 potentiostat. For the electrochemical studies, a conventional three-electrode electrochemical cell containing an Ag/AgCl (3.5M KCl) reference electrode, Pt wire auxiliary electrode, and fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) working electrode coated with 1, respectively, was employed. FTO glass substrates were initially cleaned and compound 1-coated FTO working electrode was prepared as previously described5. All potentials described herein were measured in a phosphate buffer solution of pH=10 (vs. Ag/AgCl). The cyclic voltammogram of compound 1-coated FTO electrode was recorded between 0 and 1.6V at a scan rate of 100mVs-1. The phosphate buffer solution will be abbreviated as KPi in this manuscript.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Bulk electrolysis experiments were done in a two-section cell with a glass frit separation. The auxiliary electrode was kept in one section while the working and reference electrodes were positioned in the other partition. Tafel slope data were obtained under similar experimental parameters at various functional potentials employing a steady current density of an equilibrium time of 600 s. Chronoamperometric studies were carried out without iR compensation at variable potentials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Bulk electrolysis experiments were done in a two-section cell with a glass frit separation. The auxiliary electrode was kept in one section while the working and reference electrodes were positioned in the other partition. Tafel slope data were obtained under similar experimental parameters at various functional potentials employing a steady current density of an equilibrium time of 600s. Chronoamperometric studies were carried out without iR compensation at variable potentials.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In order to calculate Faradaic efficiency, the evolved oxygen during catalytic studies was monitored using a dissolved oxygen-sensing instrument (YSI 5100) fitted with a dissolved oxygen field probe introduced into the anodic section of gas-tight electrochemical cell. The Ag/AgCl electrode was placed quite a few millimeters away from the working electrode. All the experiments were carried out under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to calculate Faradaic efficiency, the evolved oxygen during catalytic studies was monitored using a dissolved oxygen-sensing instrument (YSI 5100) fitted with a dissolved oxygen field probe introduced into the anodic section of gas-tight electrochemical cell. The Ag/AgCl electrode was placed quite a few millimeters away from the working electrode. All the experiments were carried out under N2 atmosphere.

<ce:section-title id="st045">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st050">Crystal structure evaluation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The crystallographic data and structure determination details for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond angles and distances are displayed in Table SIT1 and SIT2, respectively. The crystal structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits two unique copper(II) centers, Cu(1) and Cu(2). Cu(1) adopts a distorted octahedral geometry and coordinates to four equatorial <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligands and two axial O atoms belonging to the carboxylate moieties of the oba<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands. Cu(2) adopts a square pyramidal geometry and is coordinated by four equatorial <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligands and one axial O atom coming from a carboxylate moiety of an oba<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a and 2b). The Cu-carboxylate bond distances are ca. 2.32 Å while the Cu-OH are in the range of 1.93–2.00 Å. While <ce:bold>ARL-2</ce:bold> shows hydrogen bonding between the uncoordinated O atoms from the nds ligands and the protons on the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligands (c), our compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> does not show such features. The differences in the utilized linkers lead to major differences in crystal lattice and packing between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>ARL-2</ce:bold> (monoclinic vs. orthorhombic, respectively). This also leads to differences in the overall configuration of the layers which appear shifted in the case of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> that utilizes the bent oba<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> linkers ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure evaluation

The crystallographic data and structure determination details for 1 are listed in  . Selected bond angles and distances are displayed in Table SIT1 and SIT2, respectively. The crystal structure of compound 1 exhibits two unique copper(II) centers, Cu(1) and Cu(2). Cu(1) adopts a distorted octahedral geometry and coordinates to four equatorial μ 3-OH ligands and two axial O atoms belonging to the carboxylate moieties of the oba2- ligands. Cu(2) adopts a square pyramidal geometry and is coordinated by four equatorial μ 3-OH ligands and one axial O atom coming from a carboxylate moiety of an oba2- ligand (see  a and 2b). The Cu-carboxylate bond distances are ca. 2.32Å while the Cu-OH are in the range of 1.93-2.00Å. While ARL-2 shows hydrogen bonding between the uncoordinated O atoms from the nds ligands and the protons on the μ 3-OH ligands (c), our compound 1 does not show such features. The differences in the utilized linkers lead to major differences in crystal lattice and packing between 1 and ARL-2 (monoclinic vs. orthorhombic, respectively). This also leads to differences in the overall configuration of the layers which appear shifted in the case of 1 that utilizes the bent oba2- linkers ().

Powder XRD

Powder XRD patterns were recorded to investigate the phase purity using well-grounded sample of compound 1 in the range of 5-45°.   manifests a comparison between experimental and simulated XRD patterns from single-crystal XRD data. Experimental and simulated diffraction patterns of compound 1 are in close agreement, indicating the high purity of the synthesized sample ().

elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA)

TGA of 1 was carried out to explore the thermal stability and data is provided in  . The TGA curve shows a major single step weight loss between 290 and 350°C which is about ca. 55%. This weight loss is attributed to loss of all organic ligands leaving behind CuO (calcd. 46%).

<ce:section-title id="st065">X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">XPS analyses were carried out to investigate the chemical composition and oxidation state of elements in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor> a, Cu 2p<ce:inf loc="post">3/2</ce:inf> and Cu 2p<ce:inf loc="post">1/2</ce:inf> exhibited their corresponding peaks at binding energy of 936 eV and 956.4 eV, respectively. Emergence of shake-up satellite peak at ca. 943 eV indicates the +II oxidation state of copper, this peak was also observed later in the sample after catalytic activity ( a) . The core level spectrum of the C1s showed two peaks, peak appeared at 284.8 eV corresponds to the adventitious carbon at the sample surface whereas the signal appeared at 288.6 eV is associated to the carboxyl groups owing to air pollution and carbon contamination during analysis as shown in  b. A broad peak at 531.5 eV may be attributed to oxygen atoms of hydroxyl/carboxyl groups embedded on the surface ( c). All of these results are in line with previous reports .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS)

XPS analyses were carried out to investigate the chemical composition and oxidation state of elements in 1. In   a, Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 exhibited their corresponding peaks at binding energy of 936eV and 956.4eV, respectively. Emergence of shake-up satellite peak at ca. 943eV indicates the +II oxidation state of copper, this peak was also observed later in the sample after catalytic activity ( a) . The core level spectrum of the C1s showed two peaks, peak appeared at 284.8eV corresponds to the adventitious carbon at the sample surface whereas the signal appeared at 288.6eV is associated to the carboxyl groups owing to air pollution and carbon contamination during analysis as shown in  b. A broad peak at 531.5eV may be attributed to oxygen atoms of hydroxyl/carboxyl groups embedded on the surface ( c). All of these results are in line with previous reports .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0100" view="all">The peaks at 936.6 and 943.4 eV corresponds to the Cu2p<ce:inf loc="post">1/2</ce:inf> and its satellite while the peaks at 956.4 and 963.9 eV have been assigned to Cu2p<ce:inf loc="post">3/2</ce:inf> and its satellite, respectively . XPS of Carbon C1s is manifested in b. It shows two obvious peaks at 284.5 and 288.4 eV that are attributed to phenyl and carboxylic signals. XPS of O1s, shown in c, demonstrates a doublet at 530.5 and 531.8 eV. These results are also in accord with previous reports .</ce:para>

XPS of O1s, shown in c, demonstrates a doublet at 530.5 and 531.8eV. These results are also in accord with previous reports .

Electrochemical water oxidation studies

Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of compound 1-coated FTO were obtained in a phosphate buffer solution (pH=10). At a scan rate of 100mVs-1, the CV of compound 1 shows an enhanced anodic current above ~0.97V (vs. Ag/AgCl) that can be related to catalytic O2 production ( ) whereas a maximum j of ~0.145mAcm-2 was attained at 1.45V .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0125" view="all">In order to determine a Faradaic efficiency for O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> production, long-term catalysis was experimented at 1.2 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) at pH 10 using 50 mM KPi in a gas-tight electrochemical cell. The quantity of oxygen generated during time window of 5400 s of electrolysis, was recorded by a O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sensing probe while the theoretical amount of released oxygen was estimated from the accumulative charge using Faraday’s law for a four-electron process. Results plotted in  show a Faradaic efficiency of 95%, which indicates that the mere source of current is catalytic O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> release course.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to determine a Faradaic efficiency for O2 production, long-term catalysis was experimented at 1.2V (vs. Ag/AgCl) at pH 10 using 50mM KPi in a gas-tight electrochemical cell. The quantity of oxygen generated during time window of 5400s of electrolysis, was recorded by a O2 sensing probe while the theoretical amount of released oxygen was estimated from the accumulative charge using Faraday's law for a four-electron process. Results plotted in  show a Faradaic efficiency of 95%, which indicates that the mere source of current is catalytic O2 release course.

elements.clean_text:
Post-catalytic characterization of modified electrodes

IR analysis of the pristine and post-catalytic electrodes ( ) exhibits no noticeable changes in the absorption bands. Similarly, insignificant changes in the powder XRD results ( ) confirm that the oxidation of the copper sites is reversible and has no effect on the chemical composition of the catalyst. In order to further confirm the stability and robustness of the catalyst, XPS analysis of the post-catalytic electrode were carried out and compared with that of pristine 1. No distinguishable change in the XPS spectrum of pristine and post catalytic electrodes demonstrate that the catalyst 1 retained its structural integrity during and after the activity ( ). The XPS results clearly showed that there is no formation of any copper oxide at the surface of modified electrode during catalytic activity which confirms that compound 1 is only real specie that is catalyzing the OER reaction.

The catalyst shows a TOF of 2 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> s<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at overpotential of 418 mV. Conclusions

In summary, a novel, robust and an efficient coordination polymer containing Cu(II) ions coordinated by oxygen donor ligands, has been presented in the context of water oxidation catalysis. The chronoamperometric studies show that the catalyst requires overpotentials of 576 and 623mV to offer current densities of 0.1 and 1mAcm-2, respectively, at basic conditions. The catalyst shows a TOF of 2×10-3s-1 at overpotential of 418mV. Controlled potential electrolysis (CPE) shows that the catalyst exhibits a Faradaic efficiency of 95%. This study demonstrates that copper-based metal-organic frameworks containing oxygen donor ligands are stable and efficient water oxidation electrocatalysts.

Experimental

Synthesis of [Cu3(OH)4(oba)] n  (1) 

0.22g (1.0mmol) of Cu(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O and 0.12g (0.5mol) of Na2MoO4⋅2H2O were added to 2.5mL of distilled water and stirred. To this solution, 0.15g (0.5mmol) of 4,4'-oxybisbenzoic acid (H2oba) was added and the mixture was stirred again for 2-3min. The pH was adjusted and maintained at 5.29 by adding 0.5M HCl solution. The mixture (3mL) was poured into a glass vial and placed in an oven at 90°C for five days. Sky blue crystals of 1 were collected and washed with distilled water for several times. Yield: 51% based on Cu. Anal. calcd., Cu, 37.03; C, 32.66%; H, 2.35%;. Found: Cu, 36.85; C, 32.1%; H, 2.21%;. IR data (KBr pellet, ʋmax / cm-1): 3358m, 2965w, 1611s, 1397m, 1251s, 1164s, 993s, 777s, 671s, 627s. The IR data is shown in .

cln_elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

      

Highlights

   ⋅ A rare structural topology based on copper hydroxide layers is observed in [Cu3(OH)4(oba)] n  (1).   ⋅ Compound 1 exhibits excellent water oxidation catalysis activity in basic solution.   ⋅ Chronoamperometric studies show that 1 reaches a current density of 0.1mAcm-2 at η=576mV.   ⋅ Catalyst 1 showed a turnover frequency (TOF) of 2×10-3s-1 at 418mV.   ⋅ Compound 1 retains its structural integrity during catalytic reactions.   

A rare structural topology based on copper hydroxide layers is observed in [Cu3(OH)4(oba)] n  (1).

Compound 1 exhibits excellent water oxidation catalysis activity in basic solution.

Chronoamperometric studies show that 1 reaches a current density of 0.1mAcm-2 at η=576mV.

Catalyst 1 showed a turnover frequency (TOF) of 2×10-3s-1 at 418mV.

Compound 1 retains its structural integrity during catalytic reactions.

Abstract

An uncommon copper(II) hydroxide layer-based coordination polymer [Cu3(OH)4(oba)] n  (1) (oba=4,4'-oxybisbenzoate) has been synthesized and tested as electro-catalyst for water oxidation under basic conditions. In comparison to classical Cu(OH)2, 1 exhibits improved thermal stability of up to ca. 350°C. Chronoamperometry studies indicate that catalyst 1 reaches an anodic current density of 0.1mAcm-2 at η=576mV; a TOF of 2×10-3s-1 at 418mV overpotential value. The catalyst 1 shows Faradaic efficiency of 95%. Long-term catalytic studies for 10h at a constant potential of 1.2V indicate that compound 1 is robust and retains its chemical composition. Infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and cyclic voltammetry studies of the pristine and post-catalytic compound 1-coated FTO electrodes further confirm that 1 retains its structural integrity throughout the catalytic cycle. Our results represent a proof-of-concept for designing next-generation robust and improved OER electrocatalysts based on earth-abundant metals.

Coordination polymers have captured great attention not only due to their structural fascination but potential applications in variety of fields i.e. heterogeneous catalysis , gas storage , magnetism  and luminescence  etc. Some CPs have also been proven to be good WOCs . Recently, Lin et al. have reported that a 4-(5-(pyridin-4-yl)-4H1,2,4-triazol-3-yl) benzoic acid-based Cu-MOF gives a current density of j=0.48mAcm-2 at+1.4V vs. SCE, an overpotential value of 780mV and turnover number (TON) of 2.25mol of O2 per mole of the catalyst. This catalyst also displayed 98% Faradaic efficiency . Ferdi et al. in 2016 have presented one-dimensional copper-based coordination polymer as a heterogeneous catalyst. This compound comprises Cu paddle-wheel units bridged via phosphine dioxide ligands. This catalyst offered a j value of 1mAcm-2 at η=563mV . A Cu-based MOF with 6,6'-dihydroxy-2,2'-bipy ligands showed a j of 0.16mAcm-2 at an η=640mV against NHE . In another study, the same Cu-polymer manifested an η=520mV for a j value of 0.80mAcm-2 under different experimental conditions .

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA)

TGA of 1 was carried out to explore the thermal stability and data is provided in  . The TGA curve shows a major single step weight loss between 290 and 350°C which is about ca. 55%. This weight loss is attributed to loss of all organic ligands leaving behind CuO (calcd. 46%).

Electrochemical water oxidation studies

Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of compound 1-coated FTO were obtained in a phosphate buffer solution (pH=10). At a scan rate of 100mVs-1, the CV of compound 1 shows an enhanced anodic current above ~0.97V (vs. Ag/AgCl) that can be related to catalytic O2 production ( ) whereas a maximum j of ~0.145mAcm-2 was attained at 1.45V .

The surface concentration (Γ) of compound 1 was utilized to compare its TOF with the turnover frequencies (TOFs) of some other water oxidation catalysts. A TOF of 0.0023s-1 can be obtained at an overpotential of 418mV while the same TOF value was achieved at 358mV for Codca10 and 410mV for CoPi  ().

For a comprehensive evaluation of the catalytic O2 evolution activity of compound 1, chronoamperometric studies were conducted at incremental potentials of 20mV. A plot of the logarithm of steady-state current densities versus overpotential gives a linear relationship in the range of 397-497mV ( ) with a Tafel slope value of 46.5mV dec-1. The catalyst offers a j of 1mAcm-2 at overpotential of 623mV whereas the equal current density can be achieved at η=644mV [Cu2-Po]n, , η=750mV [O2-CuCat] , η>600mV [Co/Fe Prussian blue catalyst] . The value of Tafel slope is also less than those reported for [Cu2-Po]n  , Cu-CO3  , O2-CuCat , and Cu-TEOA . A comparison of OER parameters for compound 1 with some previously reported Cu(II) compounds is provided in table SIT3.

The stability of compound 1 -coated FTO electrode was investigated for 10h using chronoamperometry under the same experimental conditions at 1.2V vs. Ag/AgCl reference electrode.  shows constant potential electrolysis result of compound 1. The current density remains persistent until the end of electrolysis, which proves the steadiness of the compound 1 during water electrolysis and also the durability of the FTO electrode surface. CV experiments performed before and after electrolysis ( , inset) show almost no variation in the voltammograms, confirming the stability of the compound 1. The black plot in  indicates that the bare FTO electrode reveals no significant catalytic wave specifying that the occurrence of compound 1 on FTO is responsible for the catalytic OER.

Conclusions

In summary, a novel, robust and an efficient coordination polymer containing Cu(II) ions coordinated by oxygen donor ligands, has been presented in the context of water oxidation catalysis. The chronoamperometric studies show that the catalyst requires overpotentials of 576 and 623mV to offer current densities of 0.1 and 1mAcm-2, respectively, at basic conditions. The catalyst shows a TOF of 2×10-3s-1 at overpotential of 418mV. Controlled potential electrolysis (CPE) shows that the catalyst exhibits a Faradaic efficiency of 95%. The catalyst preserved its chemical composition during 10h of bulk electrolysis which was confirmed by cyclic voltammetry, IR and powder X-ray diffraction studies of the catalyst before and after the catalytic process. This study demonstrates that copper-based metal-organic frameworks containing oxygen donor ligands are stable and efficient water oxidation electrocatalysts.
